of vermont today josh bongard who is going to talk to us
about uh computer designed organisms that is uh well you'll find out about it
but he's he's in the in the business of making meat bots these days any cases it should be an interesting
talk and we look forward to uh your comments uh josh the podium is yours
thank you thank you very much dennis and uh thanks to all of you for your interest in uh
as dennis mentioned meat bots otherwise known as computer designed organisms
um so i'll just spend a minute uh setting the stage before diving into uh the subject itself um i'm josh
baumgardt i'm a professor of computer science here at the university of vermont and
the work i'm going to talk about today is a collaboration with my phd student sam kriegman
and our two biology colleagues doug blackiston and michael levin at tufts michael runs the allen
discovery center at tufts university um and so as you can tell just by looking at the
the title slide here this project is 50 computational and 50 biological so i
will given the audience focus most of my uh talk today on the computational aspect
of cdos i will talk a little bit about the biology but not too much simply because i will rapidly exhaust my
uh knowledge and expertise in that area if you are interested in in the biological details of cdos
i refer you to doug and mike um mike in particular might be an interesting uh guest for your
your seminar series uh mike although he's a biologist has a formal training in computer science
and uh therefore is a great interdisciplinary researcher as well and is doing some amazing work other than just computer designed
organisms so um before again before you talk about these little guys themselves
um i want to just sort of set the stage about where i think computer designed organisms fit within
the larger landscape of ai and robotics and to describe this landscape i'm going
to use a geometric metaphor and to start with i want you to imagine we have a one-dimensional line segment
like you see here and we can then represent uh agents or robots
and the algorithms that train them as embeddings in this one-dimensional space
so if you imagine any point uh embedded in inside this line segment
that point could represent a trained agent a robot or as you'll see shortly a
computer designed organism it is better or worse at some particular task that we've posed
to the agent and you can then think of your favorite machine learning algorithm as a line
segment embedded in this segment and that algorithm pushes points from
the left side of its segment to the right side of its segment and is obviously trying to generate agents as far to the right
as possible and as we all know uh the the deep learning revolution and the big data revolutions have
allowed us to make rapid advances in producing performant uh machines if we continue this
uh geometric metaphor and add a second dimension which which are the tasks plural that we set
before uh our machines we can still think of any individual agent or robot as a point in this now two-dimensional
uh space the further to the right it is the better at whatever it is we want it to do
and the higher in this space that point is the better it is at a harder task like
nlp compared to checkers or potentially it's more general it's able to perform well
at a larger number of tasks it doesn't really matter for our discussion today this is just a bit of a
metaphor it's a little hand wavy but the reason i use this metaphor
is like many roboticists i'm interested i'm sorry before i get to the third
dimension we can sort of think about how far we can push this idea of
creating uh better and better machine learning algorithms and some people believe in agi some
don't i don't really know what artificial general intelligence means artificial general and intelligence all
three of those terms are exceedingly difficult to uh to define but some people would argue
we just need bigger neural networks and more data centers and more data and that's it that's all we really need
and we'll eventually will continue to produce increasingly performant and increasingly general
agents but like many other roboticists and others working
in ai in general i'm also interested in a third dimension which is sometimes
known as embodiment or morphology or body plan embodiment is a controversial term it
means different things to different people i'm not going to attempt to define embodiment today
but most most people could look at the atlas humanoid robot and the humble roomba here and most would agree
that the atlas robot is more embodied or is embodied in a more complex manner than the roomba
the roomba is more embodied than a naked neural network running on a laptop waiting passively
for data so we can then ask the question or we can start to think about algorithms that
push along the grand diagonal so if you imagine a line segment embedded in the
grand diagonal here that line segment however it does it is incrementally producing more
performant machines those further to the right slightly more general machines this
algorithm is exposing the agents to a slowly growing set of tasks or variants of a task
and finally this algorithm is pushing towards the back of the cube here and incrementally
complexifying or improving the mechanical structure of the machine so that's the algorithm
that i'm going to talk about today the algorithm that produces uh computer-designed organisms has these
three characteristics as we'll see uh shortly so just to take an example of
how to sort of use this metaphor here's some work by a stanford grad carpathi
working with google did some amazing uh work a few years back using the arm farm
here so seven robot arms trained over uh four months 580 000 grasp attempts
were performed uh and generated data to train a 1.2 million parameter neural
network and at the end of those four months they exposed these arms to a set of new objects and the arms
performed well 96 percent of the time uh an incredible uh an experi
an incredible experiment but if we then try and embed this in this space what it gives us is a line that moves
through a horizontal cut through the cube these seven arms all
have exactly the same embodiment and that embodiment does not did not change over the four month
period of this of this experiment
so what happens if we relax that assumption what happens if we assume now that the body
uh or the bodies of each arm in the arm farm here changes significantly obviously there's
some insignificant wear and tear and so on but can we exploit the fact that the
embodiment of these robots is changing to improve their ability to learn
a set of tasks so as just an example of this several years ago now i worked on a
project with hod lipson at cornell university where we assumed that the change in embodiment was
unintentional and in this unintentional change the robot suffered unexpected
damage damaged its morphology changed and the control policy that had previously been trained on the
intact robot uh no longer worked on the uh on the damaged robot
we then did some model based control where we assumed that the sensor motor data being returned by the physical
machine was used to train or adapt the model to better reflect the
robot's physical state and then once it had adapted that model it could retrain a control policy
and deploy it back to the damaged machine and allow it to recover functionality
i'm not going to talk about that work today but just to give you a flavor for the kinds of things we can explore when
we assume that the body of the agents are changing over time
okay so another way to think about this if you're more comfortable with reinforcement learning is to take the
standard five tuple where we assume the agent is capable of a set s of states it's capable of a set a of
actions and we are trying to evolve or we're trying to train
a policy to change state into action we have some reward function that will
determine the quality of any given uh policy and we have some subset f uh
sub f which is a subset of some desired or final state and finally we have the the transition
function which will take the action at time t and translate it into the new state
s t s sub t plus one that the agent experiences at the next time step i've introduced a slight
modification to this formalism here which is to parameterize uh the the uh transition matrix with
m sub i where m is some description of the morphology or the embodiment uh
of this agent and we can then a and in a standard reinforcement learning
experiment of course it's the policy that is the target of optimization but what happens if the morphology
itself is changing or better yet the morphology also or m
also becomes a target of optimization obviously if we have an algorithm that
is changing uh morphology from i to j in this case it is also having impacts on s and
for example if we add or remove body parts from a machine we may increase or decrease
the dimensionality of the state and action spaces we can ask questions like if we make an
arbitrarily small morphological modification under what conditions can we
guarantee that there will be a correspondingly small change in the state state the new state
space and action space for this new machine we can then generalize that and think
about what the biologists refer to as morphospace which is the space of all possible
uh morphologies and we can then think about moving through the space and looking for gradients can we for
example move from one morphology to another in morpho space and climb a gradient
towards some desired meta state for example searching for
morphologies that increasingly facilitate an inner loop of policy training
for example those are the kinds of things we work on in my group and we've looked at that with simulated and physical rigid and soft
robots but today we're going to talk about neither of those and focus instead on meat bots of course
my group is not the first to think about this most of you will probably be familiar with the groundbreaking work of carl sims all the
way back in the early 1990s carl sims was a computer graphics researcher among other things
created his own physics engine six years before there were any commercially available physics engines
and then created at that time an evolutionary algorithm that could simultaneously alter the body plans and
control policies of virtual creatures it was a groundbreaking uh report at the time and is still in
many ways considered state of the art it's very difficult to improve upon carl sims's work
one of the reasons for that is that when we are searching through morphology space it is very difficult to
guarantee that we have a differentiable system and so
i'm going to hopefully try and convince some of you that this is an interesting problem to work on there is an open sub problem in this
problem which is can we create differentiable algorithms that are able to move continuously
through morpho space looking for morphologies that admit or facilitate
the inner loop of policy training okay so let's switch now and talk about
applying this idea to robots that are made out of biological cells this was work that we reported
just this past january in pnas i'm going to talk about the algorithm itself
and show you some images and videos of the uh cdos in action all the images and
videos i'm going to show you today are available on a website we created for this project uh in the lower left there there's also
a pointer there to the github repo so you can dig into the code if you're interested there's a link to the paper itself and
other materials so as as promised as i just mentioned we're going to look at a nested
algorithm in which there is an outer and inner loop of training and i'm going to start with this outer loop of training and in this
outer loop what we're going to do is continuously design virtual creatures not that differently
from how carl sims did back in the 90s for each
promising design we are then going to deploy it into a physical environment and see how well that physically
um how well the physical agent does compared to the simulated agent this is very closely related to uh sim
to re their sim real problem uh in robotics if you think it's difficult to
successfully transfer a relatively traditional robot from simulation to
reality or just a control policy from sim to real it's particularly challenging when we're trying to cross
uh what what my phd student sam calls not sim to real but sim to life
okay so i just want to talk about this algorithm a little bit um we're going to assume that the investigator supplies a
series of tasks you can think of these as reward functions if you like
we are also going to supply beta which is a description of the physical building blocks from which the
agent can be built in some related work in soft robotics we build soft robots
out of soft voxels that can increase and decrease their local volumes
um in this case as promised the building blocks are going to be cells that are drawn
from xenopus slavis the african claude frog we are also going to require
a couple of other parameters i'll just refer to these as theta i'm not going to go into too many details of these but you can think of
these as constraints that we are going to draw back or we are going to distill out of the organisms out of the
computer-designed organisms and those constraints are going to be information that allow us to
improve our simulation and improve our ability to uh or increase the likelihood of a
successful cinderella transfer during the next iteration through this uh outer loop
this is an idea uh that's again a very popular and sim to reel at the moment which is to collect
sensor motor experiences from the physically deployed plant and use that sensor motor data to
automatically reverse engineer or improve the simulation or the transition matrix that
we're using to train our virtu our virtual agents
okay so then we're going to go through this infinite loop where we're going to start by training an agent to perform some task
and that agent can be built out of some arbitrary number of the building blocks in beta and we're going to train them in some simulation
that's been parameterized or constrained by theta so let me unpack this
training algorithm a little bit this is actually the the middle loop there are actually three nested loops of optimization here
i'm only going to talk about the outer and middle loops today we're going to start by generating a population
of bodies so we're going to be using a population-based stochastic gradient descent method
otherwise known as an evolutionary algorithm i'll talk about the evolutionary algorithm in a moment but before i do
let me talk about the way that we encode bodies in the system we're going to
describe each body or we're going to encode it as a computational pattern producing network or cppn
this is a data structure developed by stanley and it's loosely based on biological
development and you'll see why in a moment a cppn as the name promises is a network
and here is a cartoon cppn here it has two input neurons and one output neuron
what a cppn does is travel over a a space of arbitrary dimension
and paint a pattern into that space not unlike a developing organism that is
developing in a in an egg sac or is developing uh in a womb and there are chemical
gradients that are induced into that space and we start to lay down increasingly complex patterns
across space in a developing embryo in this cartoon example here we have
just two coordinates x and y so we're going to paint a regular pattern in space what we do is to take this
particular cppn visit the first position in the space x equals 0 y a equals 0
propagate those two input values to the output neuron here g you can see that only x
is connected to g so the so at this point x equals zero doesn't matter what the synaptic weight is we're gonna get a
g of zero and place no gray at position x equals y equals zero
we then move to the next point in the space we supply that set of coordinates to the input
layer of the network the value arriving at g dictates how much gray to paint onto that pixel
and we continue that process for some regular lattice in the space and this simple cartoon cppn gives us a
horizontal gradient if we then randomly perturb or mutate this uh
network in some way where we now have a single synaptic connection going from y
to g you can convince yourself that this cppn will produce a regular vertical
gradient we can also perturb the activation functions in the neurons in this case
replacing sigmoid with a step function and this gives us a discrete gradient in this case and if we allow an
increasing number of hidden layers with arbitrary synaptic weights connecting them
an arbitrary activation functions we start to get more and more complex patterns like you see
uh in f so what is a computer what is the cppn doing as you might be able to
see by now depending on the architecture and the weights of the network it arbitrarily decomposes
coordinate transforms inside a space and then paints or deposited some material
based on those composed transforms you can uh it's obviously independent of
dimension we can paint regular patterns in three-dimensional space we could add t as an input neuron and paint regular
patterns over time this is a relatively common type of generative networks
if instead of trying to train a recognizer we instead want to generate interesting
or useful patterns which in our case are going to be
robots that are made out of in simulation voxels but in reality frog cells
so we're now going to take cppns and following the work of cheney adele back in 2014 we're going to
take a cppn and ask it to determine which voxels exist inside an empty three-dimensional space
and for each voxel that's deposited the cppn is also going to paint one of four colors onto that
voxel only three of the four colors are shown here so we have x y and z we're gonna we're
gonna visit uh 3d coordinates in the space and we have two output neurons the first
output neuron presence we're going to uh scale this to a binary value zero
means no voxel is placed at that position one indicates yes a voxel is placed at
that position if a voxel is deposited in that position we scale the value of the second output neuron to an
integer from one to four and that integer indicates which color to paint onto that voxel
so we've now created uh an arbitrary three-dimensional shape and you can again play around with creating different
cppns and imagine how they produce different shapes and different distributions of colors
onto those voxels we're going to use those colors as pointers into material properties
what do i mean by material properties once we have this 3d structure we embed it in or we send it to a
finite element soft body simulator in our case we use vox cad this was
originally developed by hodlipson at cornell we've recently adapted this to run on
gpus so we can simulate very high resolution soft body mechanics um what you can see here
are these three different materials at play um the red and green voxels are meant to be
actuated voxels so we assume there's a local actuator in each red and green voxel that can
increase or decrease the volume of that voxel all red voxels oscillate in phase with
one another so we also assume there is a local a distributed open loop controller all
the green voxels oscillate in phase with one another and red and green voxels oscillate and
anti-phase with one another so loosely based on the idea of agonist and antagonistic muscle groups
the light blue voxels that you see are passive uh passive soft material like fat
uh like fatty tissue and we can then um and i'll show you
how we then evolve these cppn's in a moment but before i do as i mentioned what we're doing
is creating an initial population of bodies on line one here we're then
going to run an evolutionary algorithm that is going to evolve different body plans and
different material distributions over a number of generations for each body in the population at each
generation we can call an inner loop of training that will train a particular policy
for that body in the cdo's you're going to see today there is no policy so like like the
robot we just described here there is no separate neural control policy it is
sort of implicit in the structuring of the body depending on where we place
these red and green voxels we get different uh behavior so we're going to assume that the policy
itself or the starting policy is dictated by theta the thetas which you'll remember
are things that we're learning from the physically deployed agent in our case it's it's going to be these
computer designed organisms assuming we do we do have the possibility of training
a policy for this specific specific body we can run a relatively standard reinforcement learning
uh method in here where we have the unrolled loop in line five here we update state we
update reward and we might return the total reward
obtained by the policy for this body so we're assuming we run this what what algorithm
1.2 gives us back is the total reward for a given body if we cannot change the policy or there is
no policy then we simply run the body in simulation or in reality
and somehow measure or integrate reward over that simulation and return that
value so after line four here we assume that we have evaluated every body
and we have a reward associated with that body
we then uh we then as i mentioned we're going to run this forward over a number of generations so this is a screenshot

bone of the analog of bone not surprisingly at least in retrospect what

in the work i'm going to show you in a moment for cdos we used a more modern evolutionary algorithm the

most visual from that species so we can see there are many species at any given time you can see

than the best magenta dinosaur robot
what what appo does as you can probably guess is it probabilistically samples from

the green voxels are meant to be passive soft material when we actually run this
uh we actually visit line three 100 times so we run 100 independent
evolutionary algorithms and each evolutionary algorithm gives us back the body plan with the highest reward or
fitness from that evolutionary algorithm and you can see what the biologists refer to as
convergent evolution here although there are robots that have different shapes they are all
basically balls of muscle you'll notice also that they are all bilaterally
symmetric which is a good thing to have if you're interested in forward locomotion
and remember that each one of these body plans has an underlying cppn that
generates it as i mentioned earlier when we talked about cppns
one of the nice things about cppns is they tend to paint regular patterns in space if we
randomly wire up a cppn it gives us a non-random pattern
in the painted space we do not get white noise so part of the reason why cppns
are referred to as abstractions of development as they compose coordinate transforms
which biases search if you're searching over the space of all cppns if biases search towards things that
have symmetries symmetries embedded in symmetries gradients
repeated patterns and so on okay so now that we have our 100
trained agents we would like to deploy them and uh this is where things get interesting
um in this case as i mentioned we're going to deploy it we're going to build these robots out of frog
out of frog cells so we sent those 100 designs to doug blackiston who's a very

from one of these impregnated fertilized frog embryos
he's then going to remove uh the cap from each of these embryos each cap contains

after removing uh some of these caps they're placed in a solution which
causes the cells to dissociate so you can see the white cells here and
again if i speed this up you'll see doug removing some of the cap or the

and okay
so after we have these dissociated cells um they're going to uh doug is going to

naturally collect together and if they're left for a while
okay so they're injected into the wells i think this is uh you can see the individual cells themselves
and the these are going to be basically the xenobot once it forms into the right shape
it can be anywhere from a few thousand to a few tens of thousands of cells and dissociated frog cells

together so depending on the distribution of uh heart muscle
cells and ectoderm cells doug can basically lay down
a meat sandwich so layers of ecto layers of uh of
skin cells and heart muscle cells you can see in this video a little bit
better how over uh two days they are re-aggregating and basically form back into a ball of cells
with at least generally speaking skin and heart muscle cells where we want them
and then in the very last steps here doug takes one of these target designs
for example a quadrupedal shape like you see here and then using using a cauterization

as you can tell from this process um in the cdo project at the moment design has

next week doug came back and demonstrated uh that he had made a sculpture of one

that's the deployment stage in this particular paper however it
turns out that the vast number of evolved designs were non-manufacturable
and so we basically worked out a protocol or doug worked out a protocol
which you can see as a flowchart on the right which determines whether or not we're able to uh whether

100 designs by by fitness a reward how well they were in the case of the best design
it did not have contiguous muscle cell regions so there were separate groups of

so that design failed due to condition b1 it also failed due to b3 which is that
it was not mostly passive tissue as i showed you before
most of these creatures are 100 100 uh muscle cells which is
particularly difficult to do and i'll talk a little bit about that in a moment they some of them did not have
a stable geometry some of them had overly complex shapes that doug couldn't build as i
mentioned the cells generally like to try and re-aggregate so if there's a concavity anywhere on
the surface of the of the shape if it's too small the z phenobot as it's growing will
basically just fill fill this in so in this case none of the 100 designs
were real real realizable in reality so we use that information
to again modify the constraints of the simulation
what we did in this case was to build in a particular constraint that that became apparent due to all
these failed designs and that is that and this constraint is as follows if you
arbitrarily place cardiac tissue in the xenobots obviously those cardiac tissues are put
together in a shape that is very different from a developing frog heart and it is hard to predict how
those cardiac cells will behave so we built in a constraint
that first of all these cardiac cells are weaker so it doesn't make sense to build a big
ball of muscle we also assumed back in simulation that
since we have no understanding of how cardiac cells will or will not
spontaneously synchronize when put together in arbitrary configurations
we assumed and said instead that in simulation any any cardiac cells will beat at
random so what you're seeing in these three videos are three
random cppns producing three random softbots and the way that we
the way that we simulate this is we assume that all the cardiac cells have exactly the same frequency and amplitude but they all
have differing phase offsets so they're all beating at random what that means in general is that what
the evolutionary algorithm is now going to have to do is try and design the shape of one of
these things to effectively de-randomize the collection at the collective action
of the cardiac cells and channel all of those independently randomly
acting forces into forward locomotion so as a metaphor imagine you had a whole
bunch of human rowers but they were all going to row at the same frequency but at different phase
offsets and your task is to build the shape of a boat so that when you put these human
rowers in the boat the boat will go straight i have not been able to figure out how to do this
manually it's a very non-intuitive design task which is exactly what evolutionary algorithms
are well suited for so the first time through this outermost
loop as i showed you we got these 100 evolved balls of muscle we failed to cross the sim to life
gap but we learned something in that failed transferal which we used to improve the biological
veracity of the simulation and when we iterated this loop again
and built in these constraints uh using theta we got back these 100 uh
these 100 designs as you can see in this second pass through the outer loop there are combinations of
passive tissue i'm sorry which is the cyan the cyan voxel so these correspond
to frog epithelial tissue and red is the cardiac tissue you also
see lots lots of different shapes you'll notice there are a couple of empty cages here which are kind of

with uh with water and so we put that put that in the simulation as well turns out that this empty cage was
exacted in a later experiment by us to carry a small payload
let me show you the best uh the best of all of these designs which is in here somewhere

and has cardiac tissue mostly on the ventral or bottom surface of the xenobot and mostly
passive skin cells on the top okay so this is just
anecdotal evidence that we could cross the sim uh to life gap so
let me talk a little bit more about this gap the first thing we looked at in the paper was to
talk about um the the ability to transfer shape so here the actual here's the
actual built xenobot down here we used we used some computer graphics
methods to compare the shape and the distribution of materials in silico
to in reality and vivo and it turns out that on average the error was about 40
percent of the diameter of the agent so not very good but not bad definitely better
than chance and surprisingly that although the shapes were quite a bit
different we were able to preserve behavior from simulation into reality so although
transferal of form was very noisy transferal of function worked pretty well here's some
quantitative data so what you're seeing in the bottom plot is uh five different instances so so
um doug built five xenobots based on this design and ran each of those five xenobots
three or four time times in a petri dish and recorded the trajectory on the bottom of the petri
dish which are the blue trajectories there should be about 20 or 24 of them
the pink trajectories are our predictions from simulation about how this design
would move remember that i told you that the individual red voxels are beating in random phase offsets with
each other so if we replay back this design and simulation multiple times we get the pink curves
as you can see generally speaking there's a preferential movement in towards uh greater x which is the
direction we evolved the xenobots to move in to determine that it was actually the shape that was
leading to displacement we took each of these five as xenobot designs and
